docs.lead_paragraph: In the biggest burst of primaries of the election season, voters in 11 states will choose candidates for Congress, Senate and governor on Tuesday in contests that could determine the political future of Janet Reno, the former attorney general, and Senator Robert C. Smith, the New Hampshire Republican who is facing an intense challenge from within his own party. More than 50 contests are taking place across the country. But much of the last-minute campaigning has been muted by the commemoration of Sept. 11. Democratic and Republican strategists are closely watching about a dozen races that have been termed critical in setting the stage for the general election.

headline.main: For 11 States, a Close Eye on High-Profile Primaries

docs.abstract: Voters in 11 states will choose candidates for Congress, Senate and governor on Sept 10; contests are notable for number of nationally known figures running in local races; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In the biggest burst of primaries of the election season, voters in 11 states will choose candidates for Congress, Senate and governor on Tuesday in contests that could determine the political future of Janet Reno, the former attorney general, and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly two weeks after their contract expired, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield insurance and the Long Island Health Network reached agreement last week on a new multiyear contract that allows Empire's patients to again use the network's 11 hospitals, including Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola and the hospitals of Catholic Health Services. Deborah L. Bohren, Empire's vice president for public affairs, said the new agreement does not affect any patient's existing coverage or increase costs to patients. She said Empire patients who were treated at a Long Island Health Network hospital after the contract expired on Aug. 20 would be billed as if they went to an in-network hospital and not at the higher out-of-network rate.
docs.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield reaches agreement with Long Island Health Network on new multiyear contract that allows subscribers to again use network's 11 hospitals, including two on Long Island (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just weeks after rejecting proposals to help the elderly with prescription drug costs, the Senate is poised to increase Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations. Consumer advocates are furious at the prospect that Congress will address the needs of health care providers without doing anything on prescription drugs, and their anger is putting political pressure on Congress to try again to pass at least a modest drug bill this year.

headline.main: Plan to Raise Medicare Pay For Providers Draws Anger

docs.abstract: Senate, which recently rejected proposals to help elderly with prescription drug costs, is poised to increase Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations; consumer advocates are furious that Congress will address needs of health care providers without doing anything on prescription drugs; their anger is putting political pressure on Congress to try again to pass at least modest drug bill this year (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR Jack Nicolais, becoming an owner of Saxon Chemists was a boyhood dream come true. Mr. Nicolais had wanted to be a pharmacist since he was an 8-year-old awed by the neighborhood pharmacists in 1950's Queens. ''I was so impressed with the docs in the white coats who took care of our needs,'' Mr. Nicolais said. ''They were very personal, very trustworthy.''
docs.abstract: Article on changes independent drugstore owners in Westchester County, NY, are being forced to make to stay competitive as chain stores open more outlets; Jack Nicolais, owner of Saxon Chemists in White Plains, says nearby CVS drugstore has made him smarter businessman; other pharmacists comment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If there is near-universal agreement that Sept. 11 changed America, there is a wide range of opinion about what that transformation consists of. For some, the change is simply a matter of perspective; for others, it is manifest in public policy, legal rules, political debate or their daily lives. We asked 12 Americans for their views on the most significant change the country has undergone in the year since Sept. 11. Stephen L. Carter What has changed since the terrorist attacks of a year ago? There are more flags in evidence, American troops are fighting abroad with widespread domestic support, and at home, in the midst of grieving for our losses, we seem to accept as more or less inevitable the prospect of a war to remove Saddam Hussein. We have proved to be in many respects a nation of patriots, and angry ones still.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed comments by twelve well-known Americans on how Sept 11 terrorist attacks have changed America, and affected their personal outlooks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN I was 8, I sold Kool-Aid ice pops on the sidewalk in front of my apartment house in Brooklyn for a nickel. My partner and I didn't let anything go to waste. As the pops melted, we sold them as soda. My mother's family was from Lithuania. My father was born in Romania. He was on his way to being an engineer in this country, but his dad died and he had to get a job. He worked for Western Union most of his life. He probably never made more than $100 a week.
docs.abstract: New York Life Insurance Co chief executive Sy Sternberg writes The Boss column, about his life and family and circumstances that led him to his career in life insurance industry (M)
